full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "California Regional Divisions" (text) focused on "how organizations divide the state into regions" (text). At the top there is a clear heading and a small emblematic map as a visual that shows a stylized state outline labeled with simple region blocks presented as a single icon: "stylized state outline with region blocks" (figure), and beside it a concise tagline presented as text that reads "regional tourism groups promote northern central southern regions" (text). In the middle a comparative panel features two symbolic club badges to illustrate the AAA perspective: "two simplified club badges" (figure) and a short explanatory line of text that states "California State Automobile Association splits into northern California" (text), paired with another text line that reads "Automobile Club of Southern California splits into southern California" (text), and a reinforcing text line that explicitly states "AAA Auto Clubs most commonly divide the state" (text) followed by another text line that contrasts the approach with the "three-region point of view used by others" (text). Toward the lower section a geographic influence is depicted with a simple mountain icon to represent the Tehachapis labeled by the text "the Tehachapis crest divides regional definitions" (figure) and an adjacent explanatory text line that reads "desert parts of north Los Angeles County counted as southern California" (text). The overall style of the image is clean, informative, and infographic‑focused with clear icons and legible concise text.
context: The state is most commonly divided and promoted by its regional tourism groups as consisting of northern, central, and southern California regions. The two AAA Auto Clubs of the state, the California State Automobile Association and the Automobile Club of Southern California, choose to simplify matters by dividing the state along the lines where their jurisdictions for membership apply, as either northern or southern California, in contrast to the three-region point of view. Another influence is the geographical phrase South of the Tehachapis, which would split the southern region off at the crest of that transverse range, but in that definition, the desert portions of north Los Angeles County and eastern Kern and San Bernardino Counties would be included in the southern California region due to their remoteness from the central valley and interior desert landscape.

At the top there is a bold headline and a simple illustration of a regional map represented by a generic city silhouette labeled "southern California megalopolis ranked third nationwide" (text) while an adjacent icon shows a stylized suburban neighborhood as "\"suburban communities and use of automobiles and highways\" (text)" and a symbolic car-and-road cartoon as "\"transportation dominated by automobiles and highways\" (figure)". context: Southern California consists of a heavily developed urban environment, home to some of the largest urban areas in the state, along with vast areas that have been left undeveloped. It is the third most populated megalopolis in the United States, after the Great Lakes Megalopolis and the Northeastern megalopolis. Much of southern California is famous for its large, spread-out, suburban communities and use of automobiles and highways. The dominant areas are Los Angeles, Orange County, San Diego, and Riverside-San Bernardino, each of which is the center of its respective metropolitan area, composed of numerous smaller cities and communities. The urban area is also host to an international metropolitan region in the form of San Diego–Tijuana, created by the urban area spilling over into Baja California.

At the top there is a small map symbol described as "simple regional map showing highways and counties" (figure) and nearby a clear label reading "Traveling south on Interstate 5 main gap Camp Pendleton" (text) to indicate that "\"Camp Pendleton\" (text)" is the main gap to continued urbanization, and a commuter icon depicted as "symbolic people with briefcases moving between cities" (figure) leads into the middle where a locator caption reads "Communities along I‑15 and I‑215 link to San Diego" (text) while another text tag states "Temecula and Murrieta connect with Inland Empire" (text) to show dual connections, and an institutional caption explains "the United States Census Bureau defines metropolitan areas" (text) accompanied by an emblem-like graphic labeled "stylized government agency seal" (figure) to indicate who considers Riverside‑San Bernardino separate from Los Angeles County; beneath that, a commuting flow arrow is labeled "Many commute to Los Angeles and Orange Counties" (text) and a development timeline strip shows "Most development occurred in the 1980s and 1990s" (text) with a small schematic of suburban growth depicted as "illustrated suburban housing expansion" (figure). context: Traveling south on Interstate 5, the main gap to continued urbanization is Camp Pendleton. The cities and communities along Interstate 15 and Interstate 215 are so inter-related that Temecula and Murrieta have as much connection with the San Diego metropolitan area as they do with the Inland Empire. To the east, the United States Census Bureau considers the San Bernardino and Riverside County areas, Riverside-San Bernardino area as a separate metropolitan area from Los Angeles County. While many commute to L.A. and Orange Counties, there are some differences in development, as most of San Bernardino and Riverside Counties (the non-desert portions) were developed in the 1980s and 1990s. Newly developed exurbs formed in the Antelope Valley north of Los Angeles, the Victor Valley and the Coachella Valley with the Imperial Valley. Also, population growth was high in the Bakersfield-Kern County, Santa Maria and San Luis Obispo areas.

context: Southern California contains a Mediterranean climate, with infrequent rain and many sunny days. Summers are hot and dry, while winters are a bit warm or mild and wet. context: Each year, the southern California area has about 10,000 earthquakes. Nearly all of them are so small that they are not felt. Only several hundred are greater than magnitude 3.0, and only about 15–20 are greater than magnitude 4.0. The magnitude 6.7 1994 Northridge earthquake was particularly destructive, causing a substantial number of deaths, injuries, and structural collapses. It caused the most property damage of any earthquake in U.S. history, estimated at over $20 billion.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Southern California Metro Overview" (text) focused on "regional metropolitan areas and populations" (text). At the top an overview banner shows a simple map icon "\"regional map illustration\" (figure)" and a bold label "\"Southern California consists of one Combined Statistical Area\" (text)" introducing the region, and then a centered panel presents a symbolic city skyline "\"metropolitan skyline icon\" (figure)" with a highlighted statistic "\"Greater Los Angeles Area population 17,786,419\" (text)" and another highlighted statistic "\"San Diego–Tijuana population 5,105,768\" (text)" so viewers can see the two extended metropolitan areas that exceed five million, while a nearby block of explanatory text "\"each extended metropolitan area exceeds five million\" (text)" explicitly states that threshold; in the middle a flow diagram uses arrows and a cluster icon "\"clustered metro icon\" (figure)" to show how the Los Angeles-Long Beach-Santa Ana, Riverside-San Bernardino-Ontario, and Oxnard-Thousand Oaks-Ventura areas form Greater Los Angeles and another branch groups the El Centro and San Diego-Carlsbad-San Marcos areas into the Southern Border Region, with a supportive label "\"Southern Border Region formed by El Centro and San Diego-Carlsbad-San Marcos\" (text)". At the bottom a simple list panel "\"regional subareas icon\" (figure)" contains a clarifying note "\"north of Greater Los Angeles are Santa Barbara San Luis Obispo and Bakersfield metros\" (text) that completes the regional breakdown. The overall style of the image is clean, infographic-style, flat icons with clear typographic labels.
context: Southern California consists of one Combined Statistical Area, eight Metropolitan Statistical Areas, one international metropolitan area, and multiple metropolitan divisions. The region is home to two extended metropolitan areas that exceed five million in population. These are the Greater Los Angeles Area at 17,786,419, and San Diego–Tijuana at 5,105,768. Of these metropolitan areas, the Los Angeles-Long Beach-Santa Ana metropolitan area, Riverside-San Bernardino-Ontario metropolitan area, and Oxnard-Thousand Oaks-Ventura metropolitan area form Greater Los Angeles; while the El Centro metropolitan area and San Diego-Carlsbad-San Marcos metropolitan area form the Southern Border Region. North of Greater Los Angeles are the Santa Barbara, San Luis Obispo, and Bakersfield metropolitan areas.

context: Southern California's economy is diverse and one of the largest in the United States. It is dominated and heavily dependent upon abundance of petroleum, as opposed to other regions where automobiles not nearly as dominant, the vast majority of transport runs on this fuel. Southern California is famous for tourism and Hollywood (film, television, and music). Other industries include software, automotive, ports, finance, tourism, biomedical, and regional logistics. The region was a leader in the housing bubble 2001–2007, and has been heavily impacted by the housing crash.

context: The Tech Coast is a moniker that has gained use as a descriptor for the region's diversified technology and industrial base as well as its multitude of prestigious and world-renowned research universities and other public and private institutions. Amongst these include 5 University of California campuses (Irvine, Los Angeles, Riverside, Santa Barbara, and San Diego); 12 California State University campuses (Bakersfield, Channel Islands, Dominguez Hills, Fullerton, Los Angeles, Long Beach, Northridge, Pomona, San Bernardino, San Diego, San Marcos, and San Luis Obispo); and private institutions such as the California Institute of Technology, Chapman University, the Claremont Colleges (Claremont McKenna College, Harvey Mudd College, Pitzer College, Pomona College, and Scripps College), Loma Linda University, Loyola Marymount University, Occidental College, Pepperdine University, University of Redlands, University of San Diego, and the University of Southern California.

context: Formed in November 1990 by the equal merger of Sky Television and British Satellite Broadcasting, BSkyB became the UK's largest digital subscription television company. Following BSkyB's 2014 acquisition of Sky Italia and a majority 90.04% interest in Sky Deutschland in November 2014, its holding company British Sky Broadcasting Group plc changed its name to Sky plc. The United Kingdom operations also changed the company name from British Sky Broadcasting Limited to Sky UK Limited, still trading as Sky.

At the top there is a simple symbolic bar-figure showing competition broken by change, presented as "\"competition change\" (figure)" and a clear headline caption reading "\"Following legal challenge monopoly ended in 2007–08\" (text)". In the middle a compact sequence combines a broadcaster award graphic, a packaged-transfer icon, and a bidding receipt, shown respectively as "\"award trophy\" (figure)", "\"package transfer\" (figure)" and "\"bidding receipt\" (figure)", accompanied by explanatory snippet texts that state "\"Setanta awarded rights in 2006 season\" (text)", "\"Setanta won two of six packages\" (text)", and "\"Sky purchased remaining four packages for £1.3bn\" (text)". Toward the bottom a section summarizes later developments using a staff-cut icon and a price-tag icon depicted as "\"staff reduction\" (figure)" and "\"price increase\" (figure)", paired with two text tags reading "\"Sky later bid £4.2bn for 2016 rights\" (text)" and "\"resulted in subscription rises and channel drop\" (text)". context: Following a lengthy legal battle with the European Commission, which deemed the exclusivity of the rights to be against the interests of competition and the consumer, BSkyB's monopoly came to an end from the 2007–08 season. In May 2006, the Irish broadcaster Setanta Sports was awarded two of the six Premier League packages that the English FA offered to broadcasters. Sky picked up the remaining four for £1.3bn. In February 2015, Sky bid £4.2bn for a package of 120 premier league games across the three seasons from 2016. This represented an increase of 70% on the previous contract and was said to be £1bn more than the company had expected to pay. The move has been followed by staff cuts, increased subscription prices (including 9% in Sky's family package) and the dropping of the 3D channel.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "BSkyB and Freeview History" (text) focused on "BSkyB channel changes and partnerships" (text). At the top there is a banner showing a simple symbolic broadcaster icon as a timeline anchor, "\"Broadcaster symbol\" (figure)" and a short headline reading "\"BSkyB excluded from ONdigital consortium narrative\" (text)", and just below that a concise explanatory line reading "\"BSkyB joined Freeview and partnered with ITV Digital\" (text). In the middle a row of three small device icons represents channels, "\"Channel device trio\" (figure)" and an adjacent caption reads "\"Three BSkyB channels available prior to October 2005\" (text)" while a sequential pair of simple arrows and a TV icon shows the replacement event, "\"Replacement arrow with TV\" (figure)" accompanied by the label "\"Sky Travel replaced by Sky Three on 31 October 2005\" (text)". At the bottom a boxed tag shows the later branding change with a catalog icon, "\"Brand change icon\" (figure)" and a clarifying line reads "\"Sky Three later re-branded as Pick TV in 2011\" (text) to complete the narrative. The overall style of the image is clean, informative, infographic-like and timeline-focused.
context: While BSkyB had been excluded from being a part of the ONdigital consortium, thereby making them a competitor by default, BSkyB was able to join ITV Digital's free-to-air replacement, Freeview, in which it holds an equal stake with the BBC, ITV, Channel 4 and National Grid Wireless. Prior to October 2005, three BSkyB channels were available on this platform: Sky News, Sky Three, and Sky Sports News. Initially BSkyB provided Sky Travel to the service. However, this was replaced by Sky Three on 31 October 2005, which was itself later re-branded as 'Pick TV' in 2011.

At the top there is a headline and a concise introductory blurb reading "Sky+ subscription changes and milestones explained" (text), accompanied by a simple icon of a remote-control device labeled "\"remote device\" (figure)"; in the middle a timeline strip contains a sequence of dated event labels such as "\"July 1 2007 Sky+ included with any package\" (text)", "\"September 2007 Sky launched women-focused TV campaign\" (text)", and "\"January 2010 Sky discontinued the Sky+ Box\" (text)", with a small schematic set of three boxes represented as "\"box trio\" (figure)" to symbolize the evolving hardware; a highlighted panel states the user count as "\"3,393,000 Sky+ users as of March 31 2008\" (text)" and another label explains access options reading "\"monthly fee lets non-subscribers enable Sky+ functions\" (text)"; additionally the infographic explicitly notes the originally charged service as "\"Sky+ PVR incurred extra subscription fees\" (text)" and shows the alternative hardware option as "\"SkyHD box option enables Sky+ functions\" (text)"; at the bottom there is a concluding diagram of a modern set-top silhouette labeled "\"set-top silhouette\" (figure)" and a final note reading "\"Sky+HD Box became standard replacing older variant\" (text) to tie the hardware and subscription changes together. context: BSkyB initially charged additional subscription fees for using a Sky+ PVR with their service; waiving the charge for subscribers whose package included two or more premium channels. This changed as from 1 July 2007, and now customers that have Sky+ and subscribe to any BSkyB subscription package get Sky+ included at no extra charge. Customers that do not subscribe to BSkyB's channels can still pay a monthly fee to enable Sky+ functions. In January 2010 BSkyB discontinued the Sky+ Box, limited the standard Sky Box to Multiroom upgrade only and started to issue the Sky+HD Box as standard, thus giving all new subscribers the functions of Sky+. In February 2011 BSkyB discontinued the non-HD variant of its Multiroom box, offering a smaller version of the SkyHD box without Sky+ functionality. In September 2007, Sky launched a new TV advertising campaign targeting Sky+ at women. As of 31 March 2008, Sky had 3,393,000 Sky+ users.

context: BSkyB utilises the VideoGuard pay-TV scrambling system owned by NDS, a Cisco Systems company. There are tight controls over use of VideoGuard decoders; they are not available as stand-alone DVB CAMs (conditional-access modules). BSkyB has design authority over all digital satellite receivers capable of receiving their service. The receivers, though designed and built by different manufacturers, must conform to the same user interface look-and-feel as all the others. This extends to the Personal video recorder (PVR) offering (branded Sky+).

context: In 2007, BSkyB and Virgin Media became involved in a dispute over the carriage of Sky channels on cable TV. The failure to renew the existing carriage agreements negotiated with NTL and Telewest resulted in Virgin Media removing the basic channels from the network on 1 March 2007. Virgin Media claimed that BSkyB had substantially increased the asking price for the channels, a claim which BSkyB denied, on the basis that their new deal offered "substantially more value" by including HD channels and Video On Demand content which was not previously carried by cable.

context: In July 2013, the English High Court of Justice found that Microsoft’s use of the term "SkyDrive" infringed on Sky’s right to the "Sky" trademark. On 31 July 2013, BSkyB and Microsoft announced their settlement, in which Microsoft will not appeal the ruling, and will rename its SkyDrive cloud storage service after an unspecified "reasonable period of time to allow for an orderly transition to a new brand," plus "financial and other terms, the details of which are confidential". On 27 January 2014, Microsoft announced "that SkyDrive will soon become OneDrive" and "SkyDrive Pro" becomes "OneDrive for Business".

At the top there is a header shown as the quoted tag "BSkyB service launch and expansion overview" (text) with a small symbolic satellite icon shown as "Satellite broadcasting symbol" (figure) to indicate the role of Astra in distribution, and a captioned portrait-style note shown as "Sam Chisholm credited as chief executive" (text) that names the initiating executives including Sam Chisholm and Rupert Murdoch and a simple cartoon of two business figures labeled as "Business leaders discussion" (figure). In the middle a timeline strip includes the quoted tag "Service began on 1 September 1993" (text) paired with a minimalist package box image shown as "Subscription package illustration" (figure) and the quoted tag "Included formerly free-to-air channels on Astra" (text) to show channels broadcasting from Astra's satellites, and another timeline marker quoted as "Reached 3.5 million households by mid-1994" (text) indicating subscriber growth. The overall style of the image is clean, infographic-like, with clear icons and concise labeled text.
context: The service started on 1 September 1993 based on the idea from the then chief executive officer, Sam Chisholm and Rupert Murdoch, of converting the company business strategy to an entirely fee-based concept. The new package included four channels formerly available free-to-air, broadcasting on Astra's satellites, as well as introducing new channels. The service continued until the closure of BSkyB's analogue service on 27 September 2001, due to the launch and expansion of the Sky Digital platform. Some of the channels did broadcast either in the clear or soft encrypted (whereby a Videocrypt decoder was required to decode, without a subscription card) prior to their addition to the Sky Multichannels package. Within two months of the launch, BSkyB gained 400,000 new subscribers, with the majority taking at least one premium channel as well, which helped BSkyB reach 3.5 million households by mid-1994. Michael Grade criticized the operations in front of the Select Committee on National Heritage, mainly for the lack of original programming on many of the new channels.

context: Sky UK Limited (formerly British Sky Broadcasting or BSkyB) is a British telecommunications company which serves the United Kingdom. Sky provides television and broadband internet services and fixed line telephone services to consumers and businesses in the United Kingdom. It is the UK's largest pay-TV broadcaster with 11 million customers as of 2015. It was the UK's most popular digital TV service until it was overtaken by Freeview in April 2007. Its corporate headquarters are based in Isleworth.

context: On 18 November 2015, Sky announced Sky Q, a range of products and services to be available in 2016. The Sky Q range consists of three set top boxes (Sky Q, Sky Q Silver and Sky Q Mini), a broadband router (Sky Q Hub) and mobile applications. The Sky Q set top boxes introduce a new user interface, Wi-Fi hotspot functionality, Power-line and Bluetooth connectivity and a new touch-sensitive remote control. The Sky Q Mini set top boxes connect to the Sky Q Silver set top boxes with a Wi-Fi or Power-line connection rather than receive their own satellite feeds. This allows all set top boxes in a household to share recordings and other media. The Sky Q Silver set top box is capable of receiving and displaying UHD broadcasts, which Sky will introduce later in 2016.

context: BSkyB's standard definition broadcasts are in DVB-compliant MPEG-2, with the Sky Movies and Sky Box Office channels including optional Dolby Digital soundtracks for recent films, although these are only accessible with a Sky+ box. Sky+ HD material is broadcast using MPEG-4 and most of the HD material uses the DVB-S2 standard. Interactive services and 7-day EPG use the proprietary OpenTV system, with set-top boxes including modems for a return path. Sky News, amongst other channels, provides a pseudo-video on demand interactive service by broadcasting looping video streams.

At the top there is a bold header accompanied by a simple satellite icon represented as "Satellite schematic" (figure), and the header is supported by a short explanatory line reading "When Sky Digital was launched in 1998" (text) that makes the launch date and context immediately clear. In the upper-middle area a stylized dish graphic labeled "Orbital service moved to 28.5°E" (figure) sits beside a concise caption stating "Astra 2A was used for the 1998 launch" (text) to show which satellite enabled the initial digital broadcast, and a nearby callout reads "Eutelsat's Eurobird 1 enabled expanded service" (text) to indicate the later satellite that allowed the company to significantly expand offerings. context: When Sky Digital was launched in 1998 the new service used the Astra 2A satellite which was located at the 28.5°E orbital position, unlike the analogue service which was broadcast from 19.2°E. This was subsequently followed by more Astra satellites as well as Eutelsat's Eurobird 1 (now Eutelsat 33C) at 28.5°E), enabled the company to launch a new all-digital service, Sky, with the potential to carry hundreds of television and radio channels. The old position was shared with broadcasters from several European countries, while the new position at 28.5°E came to be used almost exclusively for channels that broadcast to the United Kingdom.

At the top there is a concise heading and a small icon, with a quoted summary reading "22 May 2006 launch date for Sky+ HD service" (text) and a simple symbolic satellite receiver silhouette labeled "compact box icon" (figure) to indicate equipment; in the middle a timeline strip features a quoted milestone stating "40,000 registrations recorded before launch" (text) alongside a cartoon delivery truck illustration captioned "delivery truck graphic" (figure) to represent shipping troubles, and a separate quoted note saying "17,000 customers not delivered due to failures" (text) which explicitly documents the BBC report about failed deliveries; continuing through the center is a technician tool symbol captioned "generic technician tools" (figure) with adjacent quoted labels "set top box manufacturer Thomson supply issues" (text) and "STB referenced as affected set top box" (text) to identify the vendor and include the STB answer, and toward the lower portion a cumulative statistic is shown with the quoted caption "4,222,000 homes with Sky+HD as of March 2012" (text) supported by a simple house cluster icon captioned "stylized homes graphic" (figure), and finally a small footer contains a quoted note "timeline and figures drawn from reported launch coverage" (text). The overall style of the image is clean, informational, and infographic-like with clear icons and readable data labels.
context: BSkyB launched its HDTV service, Sky+ HD, on 22 May 2006. Prior to its launch, BSkyB claimed that 40,000 people had registered to receive the HD service. In the week before the launch, rumours started to surface that BSkyB was having supply issues with its set top box (STB) from manufacturer Thomson. On Thursday 18 May 2006, and continuing through the weekend before launch, people were reporting that BSkyB had either cancelled or rescheduled its installation. Finally, the BBC reported that 17,000 customers had yet to receive the service due to failed deliveries. On 31 March 2012, Sky announced the total number of homes with Sky+HD was 4,222,000.

context: On 8 February 2007, BSkyB announced its intention to replace its three free-to-air digital terrestrial channels with four subscription channels. It was proposed that these channels would offer a range of content from the BSkyB portfolio including sport (including English Premier League Football), films, entertainment and news. The announcement came a day after Setanta Sports confirmed that it would launch in March as a subscription service on the digital terrestrial platform, and on the same day that NTL's services re-branded as Virgin Media. However, industry sources believe BSkyB will be forced to shelve plans to withdraw its channels from Freeview and replace them with subscription channels, due to possible lost advertising revenue.

context: Provided is a universal Ku band LNB (9.75/10.600 GHz) which is fitted at the end of the dish and pointed at the correct satellite constellation; most digital receivers will receive the free to air channels. Some broadcasts are free-to-air and unencrypted, some are encrypted but do not require a monthly subscription (known as free-to-view), some are encrypted and require a monthly subscription, and some are pay-per-view services. To view the encrypted content a VideoGuard UK equipped receiver (all of which are dedicated to the Sky service, and cannot be used to decrypt other services) needs to be used. Unofficial CAMs are now available to view the service, although use of them breaks the user's contract with Sky and invalidates the user's rights to use the card.

At the top there is a bold header and a simple skyline cartoon symbolizing media companies with a captioned icon "\"Media companies contesting sports rights\" (figure)", and a short explanatory banner "\"Talks held in the autumn of 1991 for five-year rights\" (text)" leading into the chronology. In the middle a clustered block shows competing offers and stakeholders with a pictogram of a phone and documents captioned "\"Alleged bid leak and telephone tip-off\" (figure)", and adjacent facts presented as clear labels: "\"ITV were the current rights holders fighting retention\" (text)", "\"ITV increased offer to £34m per year to retain control\" (text)", and "\"BSkyB agreed a £304m deal for all live matches\" (text)". At the bottom a compact panel describes outcomes and reactions with an editorial-stack icon captioned "\"Newspaper influence questioned in bidding dispute\" (figure)" and a summary label "\"BBC given highlights of most matches under agreement\" (text) concluding the narrative. The overall style of the image is clean, informational, and timeline-driven with simple icons and concise typography.
context: In the autumn of 1991, talks were held for the broadcast rights for Premier League for a five-year period, from the 1992 season. ITV were the current rights holders, and fought hard to retain the new rights. ITV had increased its offer from £18m to £34m per year to keep control of the rights. BSkyB joined forces with the BBC to make a counter bid. The BBC was given the highlights of most of the matches, while BSkyB paying £304m for the Premier League rights, would give them a monopoly of all live matches, up to 60 per year from the 1992 season.  Murdoch described sport as a "battering ram" for pay-television, providing a strong customer base. A few weeks after the deal, ITV went to the High Court to get an injunction as it believed their bid details had been leaked before the decision was taken. ITV also asked the Office of Fair Trading to investigate since it believed Rupert Murdoch's media empire via its newspapers had influenced the deal. A few days later neither action took effect, ITV believed BSkyB was telephoned and informed of its £262m bid, and Premier League advised BSkyB to increase its counter bid.

At the top there is a headline block showing the licensing context with a labeled text box reading "Operating licence enforced by Ofcom authority" (text) alongside a simple satellite dish symbolized in a panel as "Satellite dish and signal waves" (figure), and this introduces that "BSkyB has no veto over the presence of channels on their EPG" (text) as a clear declarative statement; in the middle a pricing and carriage section presents a price range captioned "EPG access fees from £15–100,000 per channel" (text) with an illustrative image representing a payment exchange as "Generic payment exchange icon" (figure), and an adjacent panel explains encryption incentives with the statement "Encrypted third-party channels may receive discounts or free carriage" (text) accompanied by a symbolic padlock-on-TV cartoon labeled "Padlock on a television set" (figure); at the bottom a responsibilities and limits area contains the clarified notices "BSkyB does not carry any control over channel content" (text) and "BSkyB does not carry any control over picture quality" (text) along with an icon showing a TV with hands-off gesture captioned "Hands-off television symbol" (figure) to reinforce that carriage or content issues remain outside BSkyB control. The overall style of the image is clean, infographic-focused, informative and professional.
context: BSkyB has no veto over the presence of channels on their EPG, with open access being an enforced part of their operating licence from Ofcom. Any channel which can get carriage on a suitable beam of a satellite at 28° East is entitled to access to BSkyB's EPG for a fee, ranging from £15–100,000. Third-party channels which opt for encryption receive discounts ranging from reduced price to free EPG entries, free carriage on a BSkyB leased transponder, or actual payment for being carried. However, even in this case, BSkyB does not carry any control over the channel's content or carriage issues such as picture quality.

At the top there is a headline and a small icon, with the headline presented as a descriptive caption "BSkyB officially launched Sky Digital on 1 October 1998" (text) and a small symbolic satellite receiver rendered as "\"generic receiver\" (figure)" nearby to indicate broadcast technology; in the middle a compact paragraph-style block reads "Sky Digital branded to distinguish from analogue services" (text) while a simple stylized remote-control cartoon labeled "\"generic remote\" (figure)" visually suggests the improved picture and sound experience, and alongside that a line of text explicitly states "Sky Active interactive service originally called Open" (text) to show the interactive offering; further down a short panel includes the competitive context with the phrase "Competed initially with ONdigital terrestrial offering" (text) and a symbolic TV tower illustration shown as "\"generic broadcast tower\" (figure)" to represent terrestrial competition; at the lower section a sales highlight is displayed with the caption "Over 100,000 digiboxes sold within 30 days" (text) and an icon of a small set-top digibox depicted as "\"generic set-top box\" (figure)" to illustrate the rapid uptake, plus a small notation "Free digiboxes and minidishes offered from May 1999" (text) to show the company's promotional response; the overall style of the image is clean, infographic-like, with clear icons, concise text blocks, and an informational corporate tone.
context: BSkyB's digital service was officially launched on 1 October 1998 under the name Sky Digital, although small-scale tests were carried out before then. At this time the use of the Sky Digital brand made an important distinction between the new service and Sky's analogue services. Key selling points were the improvement in picture and sound quality, increased number of channels and an interactive service branded Open.... now called Sky Active, BSkyB competed with the ONdigital (later ITV Digital) terrestrial offering and cable services. Within 30 days, over 100,000 digiboxes had been sold, which help bolstered BSkyB's decision to give away free digiboxes and minidishes from May 1999.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Virgin Media HDTV History" (text) focused on "Virgin Media rebranding and HD channel rollout" (text). At the top there is a banner reading "Virgin Media rebranding announced in 2007" (text) paired with a simple icon of a generic device silhouette labeled "\"Generic device icon\" (figure)"; in the middle a timeline phrase reads "HDTV box available from late 2006" (text) alongside an illustrative television cartoon labeled "\"Television cartoon\" (figure)", and a concise caption states "Only one linear HD channel carried: BBC HD" (text) while another note explains "Option held to carry Channel 4 HD later" (text). Further down a descriptive line reads "Company concentrated on Video On Demand service" (text) accompanied by a small cloud-and-play button graphic labeled "\"Streaming play button\" (figure)"; a final explanatory sentence reads "Statements suggested more linear HD channels coming" (text). The overall style of the image is clean, informative, and infographic-like with simple icons and readable text.
context: Virgin Media (re-branded in 2007 from NTL:Telewest) started to offer a high-definition television (HDTV) capable set top box, although from 30 November 2006 until 30 July 2009 it only carried one linear HD channel, BBC HD, after the conclusion of the ITV HD trial. Virgin Media has claimed that other HD channels were "locked up" or otherwise withheld from their platform, although Virgin Media did in fact have an option to carry Channel 4 HD in the future. Nonetheless, the linear channels were not offered, Virgin Media instead concentrating on its Video On Demand service to carry a modest selection of HD content. Virgin Media has nevertheless made a number of statements over the years, suggesting that more linear HD channels are on the way.

context: BSkyB's direct-to-home satellite service became available in 10 million homes in 2010, Europe's first pay-TV platform in to achieve that milestone. Confirming it had reached its target, the broadcaster said its reach into 36% of households in the UK represented an audience of more than 25m people. The target was first announced in August 2004, since then an additional 2.4m customers had subscribed to BSkyB's direct-to-home service. Media commentators had debated whether the figure could be reached as the growth in subscriber numbers elsewhere in Europe flattened.

context: The Daily Mail newspaper reported in 2012 that the UK government's benefits agency was checking claimants' "Sky TV bills to establish if a woman in receipt of benefits as a single mother is wrongly claiming to be living alone" – as, it claimed, subscription to sports channels would betray a man's presence in the household. In December, the UK’s parliament heard a claim that a subscription to BSkyB was ‘often damaging’, along with alcohol, tobacco and gambling. Conservative MP Alec Shelbrooke was proposing the payments of benefits and tax credits on a "Welfare Cash Card", in the style of the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, that could be used to buy only "essentials".

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Victoria Overview" (text) focused on "Victoria economy and culture" (text). At the top a bold header frames the subject and a stylized map is shown as "\"regional map icon\" (figure)", and immediately below a compact panel reads "\"A highly diversified service-led economy\" (text)" to convey that Victoria has a diversified economy and strong services employment, while beside that a pictogram is presented as "\"sector icons cluster\" (figure)" to symbolize finance, health, education, retail, hospitality and manufacturing sectors collectively. In the middle a clear statistic block displays "\"Second largest gross state product in Australia\" (text)" alongside another small graphic labeled "\"state ranking emblem\" (figure)" and a neighboring text panel reads "\"GSP per capita ranked fourth nationally\" (text)" to indicate Victoria's per-capita position. Further down a cultural strip shows a venue illustration as "\"large stadium silhouette\" (figure)" accompanied by the quoted text "\"Melbourne described as the sporting capital of Australia\" (text)" and another text tag reads "\"Melbourne Cricket Ground is the largest stadium\" (text)" to identify the MCG and its significance. At the bottom an education note concludes the narrative with the quoted phrase "\"Home to eight public universities including oldest university\" (text) to summarize higher education presence. The overall style of the image is clean, informative, and infographic-like.
context: The economy of Victoria is highly diversified: service sectors including financial and property services, health, education, wholesale, retail, hospitality and manufacturing constitute the majority of employment. Victoria's total gross state product (GSP) is ranked second in Australia, although Victoria is ranked fourth in terms of GSP per capita because of its limited mining activity. Culturally, Melbourne is home to a number of museums, art galleries and theatres and is also described as the "sporting capital of Australia". The Melbourne Cricket Ground is the largest stadium in Australia, and the host of the 1956 Summer Olympics and the 2006 Commonwealth Games. The ground is also considered the "spiritual home" of Australian cricket and Australian rules football, and hosts the grand final of the Australian Football League (AFL) each year, usually drawing crowds of over 95,000 people. Victoria includes eight public universities, with the oldest, the University of Melbourne, having been founded in 1853.

context: Immigrants arrived from all over the world to search for gold, especially from Ireland and China. Many Chinese miners worked in Victoria, and their legacy is particularly strong in Bendigo and its environs. Although there was some racism directed at them, there was not the level of anti-Chinese violence that was seen at the Lambing Flat riots in New South Wales. However, there was a riot at Buckland Valley near Bright in 1857. Conditions on the gold fields were cramped and unsanitary; an outbreak of typhoid at Buckland Valley in 1854 killed over 1,000 miners.
